Pt is 73yo male who was recently diagnosed with lyme myelitis 
and was hospitalized. He was treated with Ceftriaxone and 
discharged home. At home, he developed watery diarrhea for 
several weeks and became severely dehydrated. He presented to 
OSH and was found to have C diff toxic megacolon. On [**4-11**], 
he was taken to the OR by an outside surgeon and underwent 
subtotal colectomy and end ileostomy. Pt's postop condition was 
moribund, with oliguria, in septic shock, and he was transferred 
to [**Hospital1 19**] for further management.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. [**Known patient lastname 10308**] arrived on a ventilator and was aggressively 
resuscitated using invasive monitoring. He was given intravenous 
boluses, transfused blood products and was placed on four 
pressors: Levophed, Neo-Synephrine, Dobutamine, and Pitressin. 
(Later, pt was also placed on epinephrine gtt as well.) Pt 
arrived with a Swan [**Last Name (un) 10309**] catheter, and cardiac parameters were 
hyperdynamic.

Given the pt's cardiac hx and mildly elevated cardiac enzyme, a 
STAT cardiology consult was obtained. STAT TTE showed preserved 
EF and no grossly abnormal wall motions. There was no 
pericardial effusion. All these findings essentially ruled out 
cardiogenic shock.

Pt arrived anuric to [**Hospital1 19**]. Pt was acidodic as well. Pt was 
started on sodium bicarbonate gtt. Nephrology consult was 
obtained. L femoral dialysis line was placed, and pt was 
initiated on CVVH.

LFT's began to rise, indicating likely shock liver.

Presuming septic shock, pt was given broad spectrum IV 
antibiotics. Given the severity of the shock, he was also 
started on activated Protein C gtt.

Despite all these measures, pt required increasingly higher 
doses of all the pressors to maintain bp. Serum lactic acid 
level peaked to > 10. Ventilation was difficult, requiring FiO2 
of 1.0 and high PEEP.

Family members were present and understood the critical state of 
pt's multi-organ failure. When pt's blood pressure could not be 
maintained, family members decided to make the pt DNR. Slowly, 
pt became bradycardic and hypotensive. Cardiac arrest ensued. Pt 
was pronounced deceased 4:45am, [**3298-4-12**]. Cause of death 
was cardiopulmonary arrest due to septic shock.

None

C.Diff collitis

acute respiratory failure
post operative anemia
liver failure

hypomagnesimia
CAD

text.2:
Admission Date:  [**2692-5-8**]     Discharge Date:  [**2692-5-12**]

Date of Birth:   [**2620-8-22**]     Sex:  F

Service:  CMED

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  Ms. [**Known patient lastname 13175**] is a 71 year-old
female with a history of lung cancer status post left lung
resection in [**2689**], status post Taxol, Carboplatin and
radiation therapy and now with recurrent lung cancer at the
right hilum status post right sided endobronchial stent as
well as carboplatin, Taxol and radiation therapy to the right
side as well, which was completed at the beginning of May.
She now presents with a chief complaint of six days of
progressive shortness of breath, fevers to 101, chills and
dry cough.  She was initially treated with a X-pack for
presumed community acquired pneumonia, but had worsening of
symptoms.  She subsequently presented to the Emergency Room
and there was noted to be in severe respiratory distress and
hypotensive with significant oxygen requirement.  She was
subsequently intubated.  A chest x-ray showed diffuse right
sided infiltrates.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  1.  Lung cancer, details as per
history of present illness.  2.  Diverticulosis.  3.  Atrial
fibrillation.  4.  Procainamide arthritis.  5.
Hypercholesterolemia.  6.  Depression.  7.  Seasonal
allergies.  8.  Hemangioma of the liver.  9.  Status post
tonsillectomy.

MEDICATIONS:  Zithromax, Pravachol, Ativan prn, Celexa.

ALLERGIES:  Procainamide and Bactrim.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  Lives with husband.  Retired bank clerk.
Forty pack year smoking history quit ten years ago.
Occasional alcohol.  She has four sons.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  Temperature 96.3.  Blood pressure
95/50.  Heart rate 135.  Respirations 36.  74% saturation on
nonrebreather.  In general significant respiratory distress
speaking in incomplete sentences, tachypneic.  Pupils are
equal, round and reactive to light.  Extraocular movements
intact.  No JVD.  Diffuse rales in the right lung fields.
Decreased breath sounds on the left.  Regular rhythm,
tachycardic.  No murmurs, rubs or gallops appreciated.
Abdomen soft, nontender, nondistended.  Normoactive bowel
sounds.  Extremities no edema.  2+ distal pulses.
Neurological grossly nonfocal.

LABORATORY:  Chest x-ray diffuse right sided infiltrates.
White count 15.5, hematocrit 35, platelets 394.  Differential
91% neutrophils, 4% lymphocytes.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  1.  Pulmonary:  The patient was intubated
for clinical respiratory distress and hypoxia.  She
subsequently developed adult respiratory distress syndrome
presumed secondary to right sided pneumonia versus radiation
pneumonitis versus both.  She was maintained on the
ventilator with SIMV mode ventilation and required high
levels of FIO2, PEEP to maintain oxygenation as well as a
significant high respiratory rate to maintain appropriate
ventilation in the setting of low tidal volume due to her
single lung.  She was started on Ceftriaxone, Levofloxacin
and Flagyl for coverage of pneumonia.  Her Ceftriaxone was
subsequently discontinued and she was continued just on
Levofloxacin and Flagyl.  She was also started on high dose
steroids for radiation pneumonitis.  Over the course of her
hospitalization she continued to have significant oxygenation
problems and continued to require high respiratory rates to
maintain appropriate ventilation.

2.  Cardiovascular:  The patient was hypotensive and required
pressors for blood pressure support.  Her hypotension was
presumed due to sepsis.  The patient was initially listed as
full code on admission.  Upon further discussion with the
family it was revealed that the patient had not wanted
aggressive care and family members decided to withdraw
support given her grim prognosis both from her underlying
metastatic lung cancer and her severe adult respiratory
distress syndrome.  It was determined that her baseline
functional status was poor and that even if she were to
recover from her acute lung injury she would not return to
even her poor baseline functioning.  Her ventilatory support
was withdrawn on [**4-11**] and the patient subsequently passed
away.

Admission Date:  [**2789-7-3**]     Discharge Date:  [**2789-7-6**]

Date of Birth:   [**2700-5-9**]     Sex:  F

Service:  CCU

CHIEF COMPLAINT:  The patient presented for aortic
valvuloplasty.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is an 89 year old
female with a history of aortic stenosis, who presented
recently with complaints consistent with congestive heart
failure, which included shortness of breath and increasing
lower extremity edema.  Cardiac catheterization revealed an
aortic valve peak gradient of 80 with estimated valve surface
area of 0.5 cm2 and severely elevated filling pressures with
prominent V waves.  Cardiac catheterization showed 30% ostial
left circumflex lesion with mild left anterior descending
artery and right coronary artery luminal irregularities.
Left ventriculogram showed a left ventricular ejection
fraction of 60%, 3+ mitral regurgitation and normal wall
motion.

The patient underwent scheduled aortic valvuloplasty on day
one of this admission, which showed a peak gradient of 60 mm
of mercury and a valve area of 0.4 cm2.  After valvuloplasty
the gradient was reduced to 30 mm of mercury and the valve
surface area increased to 0.6 cm2.  A new left bundle branch
block was noted on a post intervention electrocardiogram with
a heart rate of 75.

The patient was then taken back to the catheterization
laboratory for placement of a temporary ventricular pacing
wire.  A repeat electrocardiogram after this procedure showed
atrial fibrillation without left bundle branch block.  The
atrial fibrillation is chronic.  There were no pacer spikes
on this tracing.  The patient's pulmonary artery pressure was
61/22 with a mean of 40.  At this point, the patient was
transferred to the Coronary Care Unit for 24 hours of
observation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1.  Congestive heart failure.
2.  Atrial fibrillation.
3.  Severe aortic stenosis.
4.  Severe mitral regurgitation.
5.  Hypertension.
6.  Family history of coronary artery disease.
7.  Polymyalgia rheumatica.
8.  Osteoporosis.
9.  Bleeding colonic polyps.
10. Pseudogout.
11. Status post cholecystectomy.
12. Status post cystectomy with stoma.
13. History of gastrointestinal bleed, polyps versus aspirin
induced.

MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION:  Coumadin 1 mg p.o.q.h.s., Lasix 40
mg p.o.q.d., Lopressor 12.5 mg p.o.b.i.d., ferrous sulfate
325 mg p.o.q.d., Os-Cal p.o.q.d., Protonix 40 mg p.o.q.d.,
Prednisone 5 mg p.o.q.d., trazodone 50 mg p.o.q.h.s.

ALLERGIES:  The patient has no known drug allergies.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  On physical examination on transfer to
the Coronary Care Unit, the patient had a pulse of 66,
respiratory rate 24, blood pressure 108/49 and oxygen
saturation 100% on two liters nasal cannula.  Neurologic
examination:  No focal neurological deficits, alert and
oriented times three.  Cardiovascular:  Irregular heart rate,
IV/VI harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, mild
pitting pretibial edema.  Pulmonary:  Lungs clear to
auscultation bilaterally with bibasilar crackles.  Abdomen:
Soft, nontender, nondistended.  Extremities:  Temporary
pacing wire in right groin.

and INR 1.2.

the patient did not develop further conduction problems.
Several times she had brief bursts of a rapid atrial
fibrillation, which spontaneously resolved on their own.  Her
Coumadin was held for the procedure and it was restarted,
along with subcutaneous heparin 5,000 units twice a day until
the INR is therapeutic.  The patient tolerated the procedure
well and there were no complications.

The patient was to be discharged on [**2789-7-5**], but had a
low grade temperature of 100.1 in the morning and stated that
she did not feel well, more specifically that she was a
little bit dizzy.  Blood cultures were obtained, a chest
x-ray was obtained and the patient was held for a further 24
hours for observation.  On the morning of discharge, her
symptoms of dizziness had resolved.  She had no further
temperature spikes, with blood cultures showing no growth at
the time of discharge and a chest x-ray showing mild
congestive heart failure.

DISCHARGE STATUS:  The patient is stable for discharge home
with VNA services.  She will receive subcutaneous heparin
injections 5,000 units twice a day until her INR is
therapeutic.

Clinic for an INR check and Coumadin adjustment.  She will
follow up in two to three weeks with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **].  Since she

ventricular response on her current Lopressor dose, she may

text.7:
Admission Date:  [**2526-4-19**]       Discharge Date:  [**2526-5-1**]

Date of Birth:   [**2464-12-11**]       Sex:  M

Service:  CARD-[**Last Name (un) 2783**]

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:   The patient is a 61 year old
male with hypertension, cardiovascular disease,
hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus and end-stage renal
disease who had been hospitalized at [**Last Name (un) 5891**] [**Hospital1 **] since
[**4-13**] with complaints of chest pain consistent with anginal
equivalent.  EKG reportedly showed anterolateral ST
elevations and the patient ruled in for an myocardial
infarction but refused repeated advice for cardiac
catheterization on the 4th and [**4-15**].

The patient was transiently intubated for a question of a
systolic arrest versus bradycardic event, but recovered
within less than one day.  Again, during hemodialysis on [**4-18**], the patient developed recurrent chest pain and agreed to
a transfer to [**Hospital1 4**] for
cardiac catheterization.  Please see catheterization report
for full details and summary.

The catheterization showed the patient to have severe three
vessel disease with significantly elevated pulmonary
pressures, left main 70%, left anterior descending 90%, 90%
of circumflex, right coronary artery 90%.  PA was 72/24 with
a wedge of 34.

An intra-aortic balloon pump was placed in the
Catheterization Laboratory and the patient was transferred to
the Cardiac Care Unit for continuing care.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1.  As stated previously, is significant for coronary artery
disease.
2.  Hypercholesterolemia.
3.  Hypertension.
4.  End-stage renal disease.
5.  Diabetes mellitus.

MEDICATIONS PRIOR TO ADMISSION:
1.  Lopressor 100 mg twice a day.
2.  Imdur 30 mg q. day.
3.  Celexa 20 mg q. day.
4.  Plavix 75 mg q. day.
5.  Monopril 10 mg q. day.
6.  Folate 1 mg q. day.
7.  Amlodipine 10 mg q. day.
8.  Buspar 7.5 mg q. day.
9.  Lovastatin 20 mg q. day.
10. Calcium acetate 167 mg three times a day.
11. Nephrocaps one q. day.
12. NPH insulin.
13. Terazosin 5 q. day.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  The patient lives by himself.  His wife was
recently placed in a nursing home.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  At time of admission, temperature
100.4 F.; heart rate 84; blood pressure 136/87; O2 saturation
100% on four liters nasal cannula.  In general, in no acute
distress.  HEENT:  Mucous membranes were moist.  Pupils
equally round and reactive to light with extraocular
movements intact.  Positive jugular venous distention at 11
cm.  Lungs with diffuse crackles.  Heart sounds regular rate
and rhythm.  Abdomen is soft with diminished bowel sounds.
Extremities with no peripheral edema.  Neurologic:  Alert and
oriented times three.

LABORATORY:  Data revealed white blood cell count 9.4,
hematocrit 27.2, platelets 154.  Sodium 140, potassium 5.1,
chloride 100, CO2 21, BUN 44, creatinine 8.1.  Glucose 144.
CK 357.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient was cared for by the Cardiology
Team for the first three hospital days.  He remained
hemodynamically stable.  He was brought to dialysis on
several occasions where some fluid was taken off and on [**4-22**], the patient was brought to the Operating Room at which
time he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting times four.
Please see the Operating Room report for full details.

In summary, the patient had a coronary artery bypass graft
times four with a left internal mammary artery to the left
anterior descending, saphenous vein graft to obtuse marginal,
saphenous vein graft to PDA and PL sequentially.  His bypass
time was 115 minutes.  His cross clamp time was 95 minutes.
He tolerated the operation well and was transferred from the
Operating Room to the Cardiothoracic Intensive Care Unit.

At the time of transfer, the patient had a mean arterial
pressure of 66.  He was in a paced rhythm at 80 beats per
minute.  He had Milrinone at 0.5 mics per kilogram per
minute.  He did well in the immediate postoperative period.
The patient had a metabolic acidosis and was therefore kept
sedated and ventilated.

On postoperative day one, his Milrinone was decreased.  His
intra-aortic balloon pump was weaned and ultimately
discontinued.  He was weaned from the ventilator and
successfully extubated.  He also was dialyzed on
postoperative day one.

During that period, the patient remained hemodynamically
stable, however, he required a Neo-Synephrine drip to
maintain an adequate blood pressure.  Over the next two days,
the patient's Milrinone drip was weaned to off.  During that
period, the patient continued to need a Neo-Synephrine drip
to maintain an adequate blood pressure.  He remained
hemodynamically stable.

On postoperative day three, the patient's chest tubes and
pacing wires and Swan-Ganz catheter were discontinued.
However, after initially being weaned off Neo-Synephrine, the
patient was put back on Neo-synephrine because of
hypotension.  He remained on Neo-Synephrine over the next two
days.

On postoperative day six, after hemodialysis, he was weaned
from his Neo-Synephrine and ultimately transferred to the
floor for continuing postoperative care and cardiac
rehabilitation.

Over the next three days with the assistance of the nursing
staff and Physical Therapy, the patient's activity level was
increased.  It was noted on postoperative day eight, that he
had a small amount of bloody sternal drainage.  His incision
was Dermabonded at that time.  He continued to have a small
amount of bloody drainage following that.

On postoperative day nine, it was decided that the patient
was stable and ready for transfer to rehabilitation for
continuing care and rehabilitation following surgery.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  At time of transfer, the patient's
physical examination is as follows:  Vital signs with
temperature 98.2 F.; heart rate 84; sinus rhythm; blood
pressure 150/50; respiratory rate 20; O2 saturation 94% on
two liters nasal prongs.  Weight preoperatively is 59
kilograms and at discharge is 61.1 kilograms.  On physical
examination, alert and oriented times three, moves all
extremities.  Follows commands.  Respiratory clear to
auscultation bilaterally.  Cardiac:  Regular rate and rhythm,
S1, S2, with no murmurs.  Sternum is stable.  Incision with
Dermabond.  Small amount of bloody drainage at mid incision.
Abdomen is soft, nontender, nondistended, with normoactive
bowel sounds.  Extremities are warm and well perfused with no
edema.  Right saphenous vein graft site incision with
Steri-strips open to air, clean and dry.

LABORATORY:  Data at discharge is white blood cell count 9.3,
hematocrit 32.9, platelets 318.  PT 15.5, PTT 32.5, INR 1.6.
Sodium 138, potassium 4.7, chloride 97, CO2 21, BUN 61,
creatinine 10.5, glucose 109.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
1.  Enteric coated aspirin 325 q. day.
2.  Zantac 150 twice a day.
3.  Colace 100 mg twice a day.
4.  Erythropoetin 15000 units q. Hemodialysis.
5.  Sevelamer 2400 mg three times a day with meals.
6.  Amiodarone 400 mg q. day times one week, then 200 mg q.
day times one month.
7.  Citalopram 20 mg q. day.
8.  Buspirone 7.5 mg q. day.
9.  Folic acid 1 mg q. day.
10. Atorvastatin 20 mg q. day.
11. Percocet 5/325, one to two tablets q. four hours p.r.n.

CONDITION AT DISCHARGE:   Good.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1.  Coronary artery disease status post coronary artery
bypass graft times four with left internal mammary artery to
the left anterior descending, saphenous vein graft to obtuse
marginal, saphenous vein graft to PDA and PL.
2.  Hypertension.
3.  Hypercholesterolemia.
4.  Diabetes mellitus.
5.  End-stage renal disease hemodialysis dependent for three
years.

DISPOSITION:   He is to be discharged to rehabilitation.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
1.  He is to follow-up with his primary care physician two
weeks after his discharge from rehabilitation.
2.  To follow-up with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 64**] four weeks after his discharge
from [**Hospital1 4**].

Admission Date:  [**2838-10-8**]       Discharge Date: [**2838-10-18**]

Date of Birth:   [**2766-1-12**]       Sex:  M

Service:  ACOVE, EAST CAMPUS.

ATTENDING:[**Last Name (NamePattern1) 4090**]
HISTORY OF THE PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is a 72-year-old
male who was basically diagnosed with hepatocellular
carcinoma with metastasis.  The patient began experimental
chemotherapy on [**10-4**].  The patient presented to the
Oncology Clinic on [**10-7**] with the complaints of
orthopnea and lower extremity edema, which was felt to be
consistent with CHF.  The patient was given 20 mg IV Lasix
and sent home with 40 mg Lasix PO.  At home, the patient
reportedly diuresed about 5 kg overnight and then
subsequently developed weakness and vomiting on
[**10-8**], 2002.  The patient was seen at the [**Hospital1 74**] Emergency Department on the [**10-8**] for worsening shortness of breath.  The patient had a
hypertensive and bradycardiac episode in the emergency
department that that was afebrile.  The patient was noticed
to be lethargic with oxygen saturations 95% on room air.  EKG
showed no changes.  Labs were notable for acute renal
failure, increased white blood count.  The patient was given
IV fluids for low blood pressure and subsequently developed
increased shortness of breath.  ABGs were 7.04, 87, 102.  The
patient was intubated for hypercarbic respiratory failure.
Initial bedside echocardiogram showed global hypokinesis with
ejection fraction of 25% to 30%.  The patient was transferred
to the MICU and started on dopamine drip for hypertension.

Ceftazidime and Vancomycin were initiated before possible
sepsis.

The hospital course was notable for the following:
1.  HYPERTENSION:   It was unclear whether the etiology of
hypertension was sepsis versus cardiogenic versus hypovolemia
secondary to over diuresis.  The patient responded well to IV
fluids, pressors were weaned off.  Subsequently, the patient
became hypertensive and less volume overloaded.  He was given
IV Lasix 20 mg times two with urine output.  The patient was
determined to be highly Lasix sensitive.  The patient was
started on Losartan, Hydralazine, and titrated up on these
medications.  IV Nipride was used in the MICU for help in
blood pressure control.

2.  BRADYCARDIA:  Bradycardia was felt to be secondary to
calcium channel blocker and beta blocker in the setting of
acute renal failure; resolved after starting these
medications.

3.  CHF:  CHF in the setting of volume overload.  The patient
had positive troponin, but negative CKMBs.  Repeat
echocardiogram showed increased mitral regurgitation from 2+
to 4+.  Focal akinesis in the septum and apex, as compared to
global hypokinesis on the first echocardiogram, 2+ tricuspid
regurgitation and left ventricular ejection fraction
increased from 30% to 35%, as compared to 25 to 30 initially.

Echocardiogram findings and troponin were felt to be
secondary to strain secondary to increased blood pressure.
IV Nipride was used in the MICU to help with afterload
reduction.

INFECTIOUS DISEASE:  The patient was initially on Vancomycin,
Levofloxacin.  Ceftazidime was changed to Cefepime for
possible sepsis.  No source was identified.  Elevated white
count could have been secondary to steroids.  The patient
completed seven days Cefepime on [**10-14**].  Chest x-rays
were positive for possible atelectasis versus infiltrates.

ACUTE RENAL FAILURE:  Suspected per renal etiology versus
drug toxicity.  BUN and creatinine was normalized at the end
of the unit stay.  The patient had been getting IV Lasix 20
mg IV once a day.

RESPIRATORY FAILURE:  The patient was intubated for
hypercarbic failure.  The patient had some issues with
delicate fluid balance.

ANEMIA:  Hematocrit trended downwards.  Stool guaiacs were
negative.  Hemolysis labs were negative.

DIABETES MELLITUS:  The patient was covered by regular
insulin sliding scale.

Mr. [**Known patient lastname 675**] was transferred to the regular floor from the MICU
on [**10-15**].  He did very well after that.  He began
ambulation the next day.  Repeat echocardiogram was done on
the day of discharge on [**10-18**].  The results of the
repeat echocardiogram were pending at the time of this
dictation.  Hematocrit remained stable.  The patient was
discharged to home with VNA services on a regular diet on the
following medications:

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
1.  Aspirin 81 mg PO q.d.
2.  Flagyl 500 mg PO t.i.d. for ten days.
3.  Lasix 10 mg PO q.d.
4.  Atenolol 25 mg PO q.d.
5.  Losartan 75 mg PO q.d.
6.  Hydralazine 25 mg PO q.6h.
7.  Glyburide 1.25 mg PO q.d.
8.  Colace one tablet PO q.d.
9.  Multivitamins one PO q.d.
10. Tylenol 325 mg to 650 q.6.p.r.n.

The patient needed repeat CBC every week for two weeks and
electrolytes checked in one week after discharge.  The family
is to call Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 4091**] from hematology/oncology with the
results.  Telephone #:  [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4092**].

FOLLOW UP APPOINTMENTS:  Appointments to be scheduled by the
patient with his primary care physician [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **]. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] in two
weeks.

shock, dopamine and lidocaine drip, and intubation.

failure from worsening myeloma nephropathy and prerenal cause

only minimally responsive to painful stimuli the next day. 
Patient most likely had watershed ischemia from the arrest.

remained hypotensive.  Hypotension most likely from cardiogenic 
shock plus hypovolemia/bleed.  Patient's BP was initially 
maintained with pressors and fluid, but eventually discontinued 
since her family decided to go comfort measure only and withdrew 
care.  For that reason, patient received no transfuion.  Patient 
was extubated and was given only morphine infusion for comfort 
measure.  Patient's BP started to trend down, her lung became 
more congested, and she became more edemtous.  Patient expired 
on [**2634-8-27**] at 9:05.  Family was notified and consent obtained 
for autopsy.

vague dyspepsia, weakness, los of appetite and fatigue.

The patient was evaluated by his primary care physician and
found to have elevated liver function tests.  The patient was
jaundiced and icteric. The patient underwent a magnetic
resonance scan study on the [**10-17**] which showed a one
to two cm mass, consistent with a possible Klatskin tumor.
The patient was admitted on the [**10-24**] for percutaneous
transhepatic cholangiogram and possible balloon dilatation of
stricture, placement of external drain, placement of stent.

The [**Hospital 106**] medical history is significant for variceal
bleeding in [**2759**].  He was eventually diagnosed with chronic
active hepatitis and cryptogenic cirrhosis of unknown
etiology.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Hypothyroidism.  Coronary artery
disease.  Status post myocardial infarction.  Status post
coronary artery bypass graft in 2/2003.

Prior to procedure, the patient was afebrile; temperature was
97.3; blood pressure 123/75; heart rate of 52; respiratory
rate of 18; saturating at 98% on room air.  The patient was
alert, oriented times three, jaundiced and icteric.
Cardiovascular and respiratory examination was within normal
limits.  Abdominal examination was within normal limits.  The
patient had no peripheral edema.

Preprocedure laboratory values were PT of 13.1; PTT of 25.1;
INR of 1.1.  White blood count of 4.7; hematocrit of 43.7;
platelets of 314.  Sodium of 136; potassium of 4.5; chloride
of 101; C02 of 28; BUN 16; creatinine 1.1; glucose of 136.
AST 141; ALT 233; alkaline phosphatase of 894.  Total
bilirubin of 18.2. Direct bilirubin of 13.5  Albumin of 3.6.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient underwent PTC by interventional
radiology. Please refer the procedure report on line in the
medical records for further details.  Post procedure, the
patient was admitted to the medical service for further
observation. The surgical team was consulted for possible
surgical intervention.  During his overnight stay for
observation, the patient experienced hypertension, going from
blood pressure of 100/72 post procedurally to pressure of 85
over palpable.  Hematocrit drifted down preprocedurally from
43.7 to 26.7.  The patient was complaining of right upper
quadrant pain, weakness and nausea, which was confirmed on
physical examination showing right upper quadrant tenderness
to light palpation. The patient received Crystalloid
resuscitation of two units of PRBC's and was transferred to
the Intensive Care Unit for further management.

A CAT scan study after the patient was stabilized showed a
large, subhepatic hematoma, measuring three cms in thickness.
Intrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation to the level of the
common hepatic duct was also seen. During his resuscitation,
the patient received a total of four units of PRBC's, three
units of FFP and one unit of platelets.  The patient remained
normotensive with stable hematocrit and was transferred to
the Intensive Care Unit on hospital day number eight.

The patient was also receiving Levaquin p.o.
prophylactically, status post manipulation of the biliary
system.  Once on the floor and stable, the patient received
PTC of the left side to finish decompression of his biliary
system, considering his elevation of the total bilirubin
level.  The patient underwent left sided PTC by
interventional radiology without any complications.  A repeat
CAT scan of the abdomen revealed a stable, subcapsular,
hepatic hematoma which had not changed in size.  There was no
evidence of active extravasation.

Transthoracic echocardiogram noted a possible pericardial
effusion and this was evaluated with CT of the chest which
showed no pericardial effusion but worsening of the right
pleural effusion which extends across the posterior
mediastinum. There was also a small effusion on the left.
The patient underwent a thoracentesis of the right chest,
draining 1.5 liters of old clotted blood.  The patient
underwent the procedure without any complications.

Considering his differential diagnosis of primary sclerosing
cholangitis versus Klatskin tumor, the patient underwent
ultrasound guided needle biopsy of the liver.  The procedure
was completed without any complications.  The pathology and
the cytology came back negative for malignant cells.  The
patient was discharged on hospital day number 13, stable,
without any complaints.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
Rule out primary sclerosing cholangitis.
Rule out Klatskin tumor.
Status post PTC drainage with subcapsular hematoma.
Hypothyroidism.
Coronary artery disease.
Status post myocardial infarction.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
Levothyroxine 112 mcg p.o. q. day.
Zocor 10 mg p.o. q. day.
Multi-vitamins one tablet p.o. q. day.
Colace 100 mg p.o. twice a day.
Actigall 300 mg p.o. three times a day.
Protonic 40 mg p.o. q. day.
Benadryl 25 mg p.o. q h.s.
Percocet 5/225 mg one to two tablets p.o. every four to six
hours.
Nadolol 40 mg p.o. q. day.

The patient is to follow-up with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 743**] within seven to
fourteen days.

Admission Date: [**3482-5-16**]        Discharge Date: [**3482-5-17**]

Date of Birth:  [**3482-5-16**]        Sex:  F

Service:  NB


HISTORY:  Baby Girl [**Known patient lastname 11479**] was the 1205 gram product of a 28
week twin gestation born to a 38-year-old G4, P2, now 4
mother.  Pregnancy was notable for maternal chronic
hypertension and late diagnosis of pregnancy (several weeks
ago) because of this mother remained on Biodan/Hct for
hypertension until two weeks ago when pregnancy was
diagnosed.  Diovan relatively contraindicated during
pregnancy.  Noted to have marked oligo of question duration.
Prenatal screens O+, antibody negative.  Hepatitis Surface
antigen negative.  Rubella immune.  GBS unknown.  When seen
at [**Hospital 2**] Hospital on [**3482-5-16**] had non-reassuring pattern
and this in conjungation with other portions of history
prompted transfer to the [**Hospital1 4**]
and cesarean section, no prenatal steroids were provided.

At delivery emerged with decreased tone and respiratory heart
rate in the 50's initially rapid response to bag mask
ventilation, intubated in the delivery room for moderate
distress.  Apgars were 3 and 6, brought to the newborn
intensive care unit after visiting with parents.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  Bruised infant, deep furrowed nasal
bridge, left hand with only two diagonal creases, hand spayed
like.  Left wrist with adduction abnormality, all joints
fully mobile.  Hips normal.  Head notable for wide posterior
fontanel and sutures.  No defect.  Flattened simple ears,
rocker bottom feet bilaterally.  Sternum appears normal.
Lungs:  Coarse breath sounds bilaterally.  Abdomen benign.
Genitalia: Normal preemie female.  Eyes normal.
Neurological:  Notable for decreased tone throughout,
nonfocal.  Anus patent.  Spine intact.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  Respiratory:  [**Known patient lastname 7495**] was intubated in the
delivery room and was placed on high frequency ventilation
upon arrival to the Newborn intensive care unit.  High
frequency ventilation escalated to maximum support a mean
airway pressure of 20, amplitude of 40, Hz 15 requiring 100%
O2 throughout her hospital stay.  Her blood gases required
multiple doses of sodium bicarbonate for metabolic acidosis
and eventually it became apparent that our efforts were
futile and decision was made with the family to remove
support.

Cardiovascular:  Infant was initially on Dopamine 15 mcg per
kg per minute with borderline blood pressures requiring
normal saline boluses.  She developed EKG changes consistent
with hyperkalemia.  She was treated with bicarbonate and
calcium chloride.  She also received packed red blood
cells in attempt to provide more volume and improve
perfusion.  Infant was pronounced dead at 11:33.

Concerns for renal function secondary to examination
findings.  The infant did not pass any urine during her short
life.

Fluid and Electrolytes:  Birthweight was 1205 and the infant
was initially started on 80 cc's per kilo per day of D10-W.
D-sticks were within normal limits ranging from 87 to 105.
Electrolytes demonstrated a potassium of 7.9, sodium 132,
chloride of 105, total Co2 of 8 at which time infant received
calcium bolus and sodium bicarbonate.

Neurological:  Ultrasounds were not performed.  Infant was
provided pain medication of Fentanyl and Morphine to keep
comfortable.

Hematology:  Hematocrit on admission was 35.7, infant did
receive one transfusion of 10 per kilo packed red blood cells
in attempts to increase perfusion.

Infectious Disease:  A
CBC and blood culture obtained.  Infant was started on
Ampicillin and Cefotaxime.

Psychosocial:  The family is involved and was at bedside at
the time of redirection.  They were involved in all decisions
being made.

CONDITION ON DISCHARGE:  Infant has expired.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:  Extreme premature female, 28 week twin.

Severe respiratory distress syndrome.

Hypoplastic lung.

Status post rule out sepsis with antibiotics.

Profound hypotension.

Hyperkalemia.

Metabolic acidosis.

History of Present Illness:

his wife on the bathroom floor, poorly responsive with left 
sided weakness. c/o headache upon arrival to the [**Hospital3 713**]

3.1; 
received VitK x1. Also received Ativan 1mg x1 and Labetalol 15mg 
x1. Intubated (Versed 6mg, Succinylcholine 125mg)prior to

received Factor IX complex (includes Factor VII). Loaded with 
Dilantin 1000mg.

- s/p cardiac arrest (in setting of MI)

T 97.1 HR 77 BP 150/110 RR 13 O2sat 100%

(hip and knee flexors). +RUE anti-gravity movement in response

posturing in RUE to nailbed pressure.

ankle bilaterally. No clonus. L toe upgoing, R toe down.

Stable with neurological improvement; febrile every night 
secondary to "central fever"

HEENT: trachmask with trach collar in place: when patient is 
able to move his neck and tell team whether or not he is in

Pulm: occasionally rhonchorous

MS: can follow commands: "raise two fingers" and "wiggle your 
toes" - only on right side.

to threat), perrlB, left facial droop
Motor: right arm and leg with increased tone, but moving 
spontaneously with good hand grasp and resistance.  ; [**1-24**] mvmt 
seen on left arm.

triple-flexion to stimuli, localizes with right side to noxious 
stimuli on left arm, but no movement on left.
DTRs: brisk throughout arms and legs (crossed adductors in 
legs), no clonus.  Upgoing toe on left, has been equivocal on 
right.
Coord: wiggles fingers and toes on right.

 
Pertinent Results:
[**3235-10-15**] 
PT 21.4 INR 3.14 PTT 36.8 
Serum tox neg 

HEAD CT
[**3235-10-15**] - Large R basal ganglia/frontal lobe intraparenchymal 
hematoma (3.7x7.8) w/associated edema and moderate (1.1cm) 
midline shift leftward. Large R intraventricular hematoma and 
small L intraventricular hematoma 

[**3235-10-16**] - Slight worsening surrounding cytotoxic edema 
surrounding the R frontal intraparenchymal hemorrhage. Worsening 
intraventricular 
hemorrhage. 

[**3235-10-18**] - stable

EEG
[**3235-10-24**] - Abnormal portable EEG due to the slow and disorganized
background and bursts of generalized slowing. These findings 
indicate a
widespread encephalopathic condition affecting both cortical and
subcortical structures. Medications, metabolic disturbances, and
infection are among the most common causes. There were no areas 
of
prominent focal slowing, and there were no epileptiform features

BILATERAL LE ULTRASOUND
[**3235-10-22**] - Occlusive superficial venous thrombosis w/in R greater 
saphenous vein extending to 1 cm from the junction with the 
common femoral vein. Non-occlusive superficial venous thrombosis 
of the L lesser saphenous vein 

[**3235-11-1**] - Interval resolution of thrombus w/in
L lesser saphenous vein. Occlusive thrombus w/in the R greater 
saphenous vein, now extending into the R common femoral vein.

ECHO
[**3235-10-24**] - Normal LV systolic function, EF>55%. No valvular mass 
or vegetation seen. Mild AR, trivial TR.

REPEAT CT SCAN [**11-9**]:
IMPRESSION: 
1. Right frontal intraparenchymal hemorrhage is approximately 
stable in size. 
The degree of mass effect is approximately unchanged. 
2. Small amount of intraventricular blood. 
3. No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
67 year old man on Coumadin with very large R basal ganglia 
hemorrhage (>100cc) with 
intraventricular extension. Hypertension (in the setting of 
elevated INR) is the most likely etiology of the hemorrhage 
given the patient's history and the location of the bleed. 
Additional possibilities include AVM, aneurysm, or mass lesion.  


Neuro - Increased intracranial pressure was initially managed 
with hyperventilation and Mannitol. The Pt was sedated with 
Propofol until [**10-17**]. He was loaded with Dilantin on admission.  
Dilantin was discontinued on [**10-25**] due to concerns for drug fever 
(see ID course).  No seizure activity observed off of 
anti-epileptic medications.  After approximately three weeks 
since admission, the patient began to have signs of improvement 
of neurological status.  He began following commands to raise 
his hand, and several days later, openned his eyes spontaneously 
and was moving his right side purposefully.  According to 
nurses, he was able to talk a bit, although this was not 
observed by our team.  See "Physical exam" section for discharge 
exam.

CV - Blood pressure initially controlled with Labetalol gtt. 
Transitioned to Metoprolol, Diltiazem was added for improved 
rate control of intermittent atrial fibrillation.  The week of 
[**11-5**], he had increased heart rate with low blood 
pressures, and was unable to tolerate these antihypertensives.  
His cardiologist Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2936**] was contacted, and with his 
suggestion, the patient was loaded with digoxin and started on 
0.125 mg each day of digoxin.  He tolerated this dose well, and 
when his heart rate trended up the following week, the digoxin 
dose was increased to 0.250 mg.  Diltiazem was continued but 
with strict holding parameters for sbp<105 (and hr 60).  
Metoprolol was discontinued, as his blood pressures had dropped 
to the 80s systolic.

Resp - The patient was intubated initially and ventilated.  A 
tracheostomy was placed on [**10-19**]. He was eventually weaned off 
ventilator support to O2 via trach collar and mask.  He was 
tolerating 20% FiO2 on the day of discharge, with plans to wean 
O2 further to tolerate sats<93%.

FEN/GI - Percutaneous gastrostomy tube was placed on [**10-19**], 
currently tolerating feeds well.

ID - At the time of admission, Pt was being treated with Keflex 
for a LLE cellulitis. Started Cefazolin IV. Became febrile on 
[**10-16**] despite resolving cellulitis. Remained febrile through 
[**10-31**]. Treated with Vancomycin and Levofloxacin during this time 
period, initially empiric treatment for presumed aspiration 
pneumonia. However fever persisted after CXR improved and weaned 
from ventilator support. Extensive fever workup (in conjunction 
with consulting ID service) included multiple negative blood, 
urine and sputum cultures, negative Cdiff, negative 
chest/abd/pelvis CT, and negative echocardiogram (no 
vegetations). One out of >10 blood cultures  grew two colonies 
of coag negative staph at >24hours, thought to represent a 
contaminated specimen. Drug fever was considered, but fever 
persisted after discontinuation of Dilantin. All central lines 
were removed and cultured as well. Fever resolved on [**11-1**], 
exact source of fever remained unclear. However, he then had a 
repeat fever on [**11-2**], and had positive lower extremity 
ultrasounds for clot in the femoral vein.  (See below.)  Despite 
treatment, he continued to spike daily.  ID was involved and 
suggested discontinuing all antibiotics when he had low-grade 
temperatures.  This was done, and within days, he continued to 
spike to 101.  A C-Diff that was sent earlier came back 
positive, and metronidazole was started, for a 14 day total 
course.  Unfortunately, even seven days into treatment, he 
remained febrile.  This was felt to be likely related to 
"central fever," with his intracranial damage.  To be sure, a 
white blood cell tagged scan was performed on the day of 
discharge.  This was significant for some uptake at the trach 
site, which could be consistent with the presence of granulation 
tissue from placement in late September.  This was not 
considered his fever source, thus the source was considered to 
be "central fever," which can occur in patients with significant 
head injury.  His 14 day course of metronidazole should be 
completed; if he is febrile (as he has been every night), 
central fever should be considered the primary cause.  If 
infection is suspected, other markers should be used for 
workup-- ie, increased secretions or cough, low O2 sats, 
diarrhea, hematuria, etc. rather than fever.  CBC should be 
checked, and the trach site should be inspected.

Heme: Coagulopathy (INR 3.2) on admission was reversed with FFP, 
Proplex, and three day course of Vitamin K. Received additional 
FFP prior to PEG placement. Superficial LE thrombi, now with 
non-occlusive thrombus in the R common femoral vein. HCT stable. 
 On [**11-2**], lower extremity ultrasounds were performed to look 
for lower ext DVTs and initially found superficial clot only.  
Repeat scan 10 days later showed extension of the right 
superficial saphenous clot into the common 
femoral(non-occlusive).  This alone may cause low grade fevers.  
Based on this, we felt he needed protection from PE.  Given that 
his bleed is several weeks ago, we felt comfortable slowly 
restarting coumadin.  This was done slowly and he was closely 
monitored for rebleeding.  

Renal - Creatinine increased to a max of 3.0 on [**10-20**]. Mannitol 
and Captopril were stopped, and the creatinine returned to 
baseline of 0.6-1.0, where it has since remained.

Ortho - Pt was found down. C-spine imaging negative for 
fracture, but patient must be awake and able to answer "yes" or 
"no" to pain in order for his c-spine to be cleared.  For this 
reason, he remains in a collar.  At rehab, once he is able to do

Endo - Normoglycemia maintained with insulin sliding scale as an

CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: None.

INDICATION: Status post fall, now chest pain.

TECHNIQUE: MD[**MD Number 2395**] used to obtain contiguous axial images from 
the thoracic inlet to the pubic symphysis after the 
administration of IV contrast. Coronal and sagittal reformats 
were also obtained.

CT CHEST WITH IV CONTRAST: There are moderate dependent 
atelectatic changes. Linear atelectasis is seen at left lung 
base. There is increased interstitial markings, which, in this 
case, probably indicate a degree of mild fluid overload. An 
ill-defined 1-cm nodule is seen in the anterolateral right upper 
lobe. A small rounded 3-mm pulmonary nodule is seen more 
inferiorly in the right middle lobe. There are shotty 
mediastinal lymph[**MD Number 298**] and a calcified lymph node in the right 
paratracheal region, measuring 13 mm. Other lymph[**MD Number 298**] are not 
pathologically enlarged. The aorta is normal in caliber, without 
evidence of dissection. There are coronary vascular 
calcifications, most notably in the left anterior descending and 
circumflex arteries. No pericardial effusion is present.

CT ABDOMEN WITH IV CONTRAST: No intra-abdominal free fluid is 
seen. There is no free air. The liver, spleen, kidneys, 
pancreas, and left adrenal all appear to be within normal 
limits. A tiny 7-mm low-density lesion is seen in the adrenal 
gland, of uncertain significance. The gallbladder is not 
visualized; the extra-hepatic common bile duct appears 
prominent, measuring approximately 1-cm in diameter. The aorta 
is normal in caliber, with mural calcifications. The major 
arteries are patent. There is some atheromatous plaque in the 
aorta, but there is no evidence of dissection. In the right 
lower quadrant, there is a 23 x 18 mm soft tissue lesion with a 
central calcification. The appendix is not visualized. Please 
note that this is non- oral contrast scan, and therefore is 
limited in terms of evaluation of the bowel. The sigmoid 
contains diverticulosis, without diverticulitis. The bladder 
contains a Foley with non-dependent air. Distal ureters appear 
unremarkable. Prostate appears slightly enlarged. No free air or 
free fluid is seen in the pelvis.

There is a chronic-appearing wedge configuration of T7 and T8, 
without evidence of retropulsion of fragments into the spinal 
canal. There are degenerative changes throughout, with loss of 
disc height at several levels including L3-4 and L4-5. L5-S1 
shows mild grade 1 anterolisthesis of L5. There is a comminuted 
fracture through the right proximal femur.

Multiplanar reformats were essential in delineating the findings 
above.

IMPRESSION:
1. No evidence of aortic dissection. Coronary vascular 
calcifications noted.

2. Proximal right femoral fracture.

3. 2.3 cm soft tissue mass in right lower quadrant with single 
large calcification which may represent appendicolith. Followup 
study in 3 months recommended to ensure stability.

4. Mild cardiac failure.

5. 3-mm nodule and ill-defined 1-cm nodule in right upper lobe. 
In the absence of known primary malignancy, followup CT scan can 
be obtained in one year to ensure stability.

6. Prominence of biliary system probably related to absence of 
gallbladder.

7. Calcified mediastinal lymph node which may represent prior 
tuberculosis.

8. Emphysematous changes of the lungs.

Preliminary findings were discussed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5399**] by telephone 
at 4 o'clock p.m., [**2716-4-1**].

Admission Date:  [**3090-10-24**]       Discharge Date:  [**3090-11-4**]

Date of Birth:   [**3005-3-22**]       Sex:  M

Service:  Neurosurgery

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is an 85-year-old
gentleman who was in his usual state of health until he was
found by his wife in the basement on the floor.  The patient
said that his legs gave out on him and he hit his head with
no loss of consciousness but had a headache after the fall
and was unable to get up.  The patient has reported that he
has fallen 3-4 times in the last month and felt unsteady on
his feet with no complaints of chest pain or dizziness.  The
patient has a past medical history of CAD, status post CABG,
hypercholesterolemia, status post chole, right knee surgery,
has no known allergies.

MEDICATIONS:  On admission include Zocor, Aspirin, Vitamin E
and KCL.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  The patient lives with his wife.  Has 4-5
drinks per week, no tobacco, quit 20 years ago.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  Blood pressure 105/58, respiratory
rate 22, saturation 94% on 2 liters and heart rate 72.  He
was an elderly gentleman in no acute distress with lateral
neck pain to palpation.  He was anicteric.  OP's were clear.
Lungs clear to auscultation.  Cardiovascular, regular rate
and rhythm, no murmur, rub or gallop.  Abdomen soft, positive
bowel sounds, nontender, non distended.  Extremities, no
clubbing, cyanosis or edema.  Neuro, patient was awake,
alert, oriented times three, extraocular movements intact
with no nystagmus.  Pupils were equal, round and reactive to
light, 2 down to 1 mm bilaterally, fundi difficult to
visualize.  Face, tongue, palpate symmetric.  Normal bulk and
tone to all extremities.  He was [**5-3**] in muscle strength in
all muscle groups.  He had no drift.  Sensory exam was intact
to light touch and pinprick throughout.  Finger to nose
missed target on the right field and denied diplopia.  MRI of
the brain shows left putaminal infarct and mild
intraventricular hemorrhage with no clear cut hydrocephalus.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient was admitted to the surgical
Intensive Care Unit for close monitoring.  He was followed by
the neuro stroke service who recommended getting an angiogram
to rule out an aneurysm bleed secondary to the large
proportion of blood on head CT.  On [**3090-10-28**] the patient's
mental status deteriorated.  He only opened his eyes to
sternal rub.  He moved his upper extremities spontaneously.

in the lower extremities.  The patient was sent for a stat

ventricular drain placed without complications.  The patient
then proceeded to angiogram which was negative for any
aneurysm.  After drain placement the patient was arousable to
verbal stimuli, EOM's were full, followed commands, moving
all extremities with anti gravity strength.  The patient's
ventricular drain was in place until [**3090-10-31**].  The patient
was transferred to the regular floor where his neurologic
status continued to improve.  He was awake, alert and
oriented times three, moving all extremities, followed by
physical therapy and Occupational therapy and found to
require rehab prior to discharge to home.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:  Protonix 40 mg po q day, Metoprolol
25 mg po bid, salt tabs 2 gm po bid.  The patient has had

PO assessment was conducted with ice chips, water and nectar

SUMMARY / IMPRESSION: 
[**Known patient firstname 2659**] [**Known patient lastname 1275**] may be aspirating thin liquids because she says 
she feel like coughing consistently after drinking water.  
However, she appears safe to drink nectar thick liquids and to 
eat pureed or ground solids if she alternates between bites and 
sips. She could not swallow a whole pill today with nectar thick 

orange juice or whole in applesauce, but she swallowed her pill 
crushed in custard w/a sip of nectar to follow.  
This swallowing pattern correlates to a Dysphagia Outcome 
Severity Scale (DOSS) rating of Level 4, Mild to moderate 
dysphagia with 2 consistnecy restrictions and intermittent 
supervision/cueing. This dysphagia is likely due to her old 
strokes. 
 
RECOMMENDATIONS: 
1. Diet of ground solids and Nectar thick liquids with  
Pills crushed in puree 
 
2. Supervision w/meals 
Alternate between bites and sips 
 
3. If there are further concerns about aspiration on this diet, 
we would be happy to perform a FEES evaluation. She would 
not be a candidate for a Videoswallow because she is too 
large to fit into the fluoroscope. 
 
These recommendations were shared with the patient, nurse and 
medical team.

Service: cardiac surgery
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is a 78 year old
female with diabetes, hypertension and congestive heart
failure who was seen at [**Hospital 770**] Hospital one week ago for
chest pain associated with nausea, vomiting radiating down
both arms.  It was relieved with oxygen and nitroglycerin.
Patient was diagnosed with a non-ST elevation MI.  She was
treated with Lovenox, beta blockers and nitrates.  Patient
was catheterized and shown to have three vessel disease.
Patient has been transferred to [**Hospital1 25**] for coronary artery
bypass graft procedure.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Noninsulin dependent diabetes
mellitus.  Pulmonary fibrosis.  Hypertension with diastolic
dysfunction.  CHF.  DVT.  PVD.  Diverticulosis.  Basal cell
carcinoma.  History of endometrial cancer.  Cholecystectomy.
Mitral regurgitation.

MEDICATIONS:  Coumadin 2.5 q.o.d. and 5 q.o.d., Imdur 30
q.d., captopril 25 mg t.i.d., regular insulin sliding scale,
Lopressor 12.5 mg b.i.d., aspirin 325 mg q.d., Cystospaz 0.15
mg b.i.d., digoxin 0.25 mg q.d., Advair 50/500 one puff
b.i.d., potassium chloride 20 mEq q.d., Tylenol 650 mg p.r.n.

ALLERGIES:  Sulfa drugs.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  The patient is married and lives with
husband.  Does not smoke.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  In general, patient was obese, not in
acute distress.  She is alert and oriented times three.
HEENT pupils equally round and reactive to light.
Extraocular movements intact.  Mucous membranes moist.  No
JVD.  No bruits.  Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Heart regular rate and rhythm, 1/6 systolic ejection murmur.
Abdomen soft, nondistended, nontender, no masses.
Extremities 4+ pitting edema bilateral lower extremities.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  Cardiac cath showed an ejection fraction of
30%, mitral regurgitation, three vessel disease.  Pulmonary
medicine was consulted due to patient's pulmonary problems.
Pulmonary function tests were obtained.  Chest x-ray was
obtained.  ABG was obtained.  It was decided per these
results to take patient to the operating room.  Patient was
operated on [**3284-2-24**].  Coronary artery bypass times two was
performed with LIMA to LAD and 5 mm [**Doctor Last Name 3879**]-Tex graft to distal
RCA.  Patient appeared to tolerate the procedure all right
and was transferred to the cardiothoracic surgery ICU
postoperatively.  She had chest tubes and pacing wires in
place.  She initially required a Levophed drip.  She was
started on beta blockers, digoxin.  She received vancomycin
times four perioperatively.  Patient was started on captopril
in addition to digoxin and Lopressor.  She was recoumadinized
with a temporary heparin drip.  She was also started on Lasix
to help treat her extensive positive fluid status.

The patient was transferred to the regular cardiothoracic
floor on [**3284-2-28**] in good condition, chest tubes and pacing
wires having already been removed.  Lopressor was increased
to improve her blood pressure.  Physical therapy has worked
extensively with patient and has judged that patient would
benefit greatly from outpatient rehab.  It is now [**3284-2-29**] and
patient will likely be discharged tomorrow on [**3284-3-1**] to a
rehab facility.  Patient should follow up with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 394**] in
four weeks, with her PCP, [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **]. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 936**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 4208**], in one to two
weeks and her cardiologist in two to three weeks.  She should
avoid strenuous activity.  She should not drive while on pain
medications.  She may shower, but should not take baths for 3

the gastroesophageal junction. There is a Swan-Ganz catheter 
entering from inferior approach.  The distal tip is within the 
origin of the right pulmonary artery and has migrated more 
proximally since the previous study.  The opacity within the 
left upper lobe is less well seen on today's study.  There 
remains a left retrocardiac opacity 
and subsegmental atelectasis at the left base.  Blunting of 
bilateral 
costophrenic angles are identified consistent with pleural 
effusions. 
.
CXR [**2726-4-4**]: The Swan-Ganz catheter entering from a femoral 
approach has been pulled back and the tip is now in the RA.  The 
endotracheal tube and nasogastric tube are appropriate sited and 
unchanged in position.  There remains some cardiomegaly. There 
are bilateral pleural effusions.  There is a left retrocardiac

Brief Hospital Course:
82 F with PMH hyperchol, HTN with STEMI not amenable to CABG 
([**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) 7012**], LAD), with cardiogenic shock, who eventually passed 
away.

# STEMI and cardiogenic shock:
(1) Ischemia:
Patient had significant CAD on cath s/p DES to LMain, LAD, LCX.  
During cath, results showed 3VD with critical left main disease, 
and severe cardiogenic shock.  Successful placement of an IABP, 
and successful PCI of the LMCA into the LAD were performed.  
Cardiac enzymes were elevated with CK peak 1215, MB 124, Trop 
4.68, but EKG was unchanged.  A balloon pump was placed in the 
CCU for cardiogenic shock, and the balloon pump was successfully 
removed with good hemodynamic control.  The patient remained 
sedated and intubated, so whether the patient was experiencing 
CP or symptoms could not be assessed.  Patient was maintained on 
ASA, plavix, statin.  She was not given BB/ACE because of 
cardiogenic shock.
.  
(2) Pump:
ECHO revealed EF 25% with 3+MR.  [**Name13 (STitle) **] was maintained on dopa 
and IABP in the CCU.  Dopamine was switched to levophed because 
of signs of sepsis, and was gradually weaned off.  Because of 
signs of sepsis, the IABP and PA catheter were removed, and an 
IJ line was used for CVP monitoring, which was kept around 12.  
MAP was maintained >65.  UO was maintained at >30cc/hr.
.  
(3) Rhythm:  
In the cath lab, the patient had 1 episode of VTach x 1 minute, 
and was loaded with amio and lido, and the patient did not 
require DCCV.  The patient was in NSR for the remainder of 
admission with no events on tele.
.  
#. Resp Failure:  
Pt was intubated at OSH for resp failure, presumed [**3-11**] to CHF 
and 3+ MR.  [**Name13 (STitle) **] maintained good oxygenation and ventilation, 
patient had a difficult time being weaned from the vent.  
Swan-Ganz was placed in the CCU for monitoring.
.  
#. Heme: 
Hct decreased from baseline of 30 to 28 -> 24 -> 28, and 
received several units RBC to maintain Hct >28. Platelets were 
stable at around 100.  On smear were monocyte blasts and NRBC, 
and MDS was considered.  Patient was HIT negative, DIC and 
hemolysis labs were negative.  
.  
#. ARF: 
Baseline Cr for patient was 1.1, and Cr was up to 1.4.  Etiology 
was likely multifactorial, due to prerenal state, ATN and 
contrast nephropathy contributing.  
.  
#. ID:
Patient had signs of sepsis in the CCU, with temp spikes, low 
SVR, and hyperdynamic CO/CI.  Patient was on levophed, which was 
difficult to wean.  Patient was given antibiotics including 
Ceftriaxone, Levo, Vanco, Flagyl.  Sputum culture was negative, 
but showed 3+ GPC.  Source of sepsis was not found, and IABP and 
PA catheter were appropriately removed.
.  
#. Hypothyroidism:
Stable at baseline.  Patient was not given synthroid inhouse 
because of ventricular arrhythmia early during admission.
.  
# Death:
On [**2726-4-8**] at 8 PM, the patient's HCP, son [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Known patient lastname 13305**], and 
his sister, wished to make the patient CMO and withdraw care.  
This was discussed with the patient's PCP, [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 218**]. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 850**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], 
who spoke with the family regarding withdrawal of care.  The HCP 
agreed to withdraw care, morphine gtt was started, and patient 
passed in comfort surrounded by family.

Lipitor 20 QD
Metoprolol 50 BID
Ranitidine 300 QD
Salsalate 750 BID
Triamcinolone 0.025% BID

Patient passed away.

Mr. [**Known patient lastname 8105**] Foley catheter was discontinued on [**6-18**],
but since he did not void for the next eight hours and
complained of severe abdominal discomfort as well as penile
pain, the Foley catheter was reinserted at 11:00 p.m. that
night.  He had no further episode of hematuria or frank blood
in his urine.  In light of his urinary retention of unknown
etiology, his Foley catheter is to remain in place upon
discharge.

He is to follow-up with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] in Urology in one week
after discharge.

A renal ultrasound was performed on [**6-20**] to rule out any
post-renal failure.  It revealed a right kidney with two
simple cysts; otherwise, no evidence of hydronephrosis, mass
or stone.  Similarly, a scrotal ultrasound was performed the
same date and showed a left varicocele, right hydrocele and
multiple testicular as well as epididymal cysts.

The patient remained on Telemetry throughout his hospital
course without any further events except occasional premature
ventricular contractions.  On the night of [**6-20**], he
complained of weakness, diaphoresis and shortness of breath.
An EKG was immediately performed and fortunately showed no
change from that of one taken a few days earlier.

His electrolytes were checked on a daily basis and repleted
as needed.  He was continued on his cardiac medications
except his ACE inhibitor in light of his mild renal
insufficiency.  His blood pressure and heart rate both
remained well controlled.  He was also continued on his
diabetic medications and as a result, his blood sugars
remained well controlled.  His Levaquin was discontinued on
[**6-21**], after a full week course, for his presumed urinary
tract infection.

He is currently in stable condition and awaiting a bed at a
rehabilitation facility.  He will be discharged as soon as
this bed is available.

with several right-sided ribs periosteal reaction consistent

multiple nodular opacities consistent with metastatic disease,

.

Brief Hospital Course:
61yo woman with history of metastatic mesothelioma recently s/p 
cycle 2 of Alimta chemotherapy initially presented with 
SIRS/sepsis with fever and hypotension requiring volume 
resuscitation and pressor therapy; now called out from MICU, 
hemodynamically stable and initially on broad spectrum 
antibiotics without focal infectious source to date, being 
treated for ongoing n/v.  
.  
1. Hypotension (thought intially to be sepsis): Pt initially 
admitted to ICU and was thought to have sepsis supported at 
presentation by fever, leukopenia, hypotension requiring volume 
resuscitation and pressor therapy.  She was treated with empiric 
broad spectrum antibiotics, however there has been no clear 
focal infectious source identified to date.  It may well have 
been transient bacteremia in setting of recent chemotherapy, 
mucositis, and bacterial translocation across the gut mucosa.  
Urine and blood cultures remain negative to date.  Stool c diff 
toxin negative x1, second pending at time of discharge.  We 
discontinued cefipime and vanco given afebrile without specific 
source ever identified, and vital signs remained stable. The 
right IJ catheter was removed with catheter tip sent for 
culture, neg to date.  
.  
2. Nausea/vomiting/diarrhea- Pt initially sent with severe 
nausea and vomiting which was likely due to side effect of 
recent chemotherapy. She was treated symptomatically and 
supported with IV fluids.  Both nausea and vomiting were under 
better control with compazine.  As well diarrhea was treated 
with loperamide.  Stool cultures/c diff was negative. Still 
awaiting final stool studies result.  Diet was advanced as 
patient tolerated.
.  
3. The patient had  ARF at presentation, which was felt most 
likely pre-renal etiology and resolved.
.  
4. Rash: Pt was found to have rash on presentation.  This was 
thought likely associated with chemo as pt had similar rash [**1-14**] 
to cycle #1. Rash improving on day of discharge.
.  
5. Metastatic Mesothelioma  Pt was not treated while inpatient.  
Follow up treatment will be determined by primary oncologists.
.

in ICU. Per report there was no real seizure activity, though 
patient convinced she had a seizure.  It is thought that the 
jerking likely [**1-14**] anxiety.  MRI of the head was obtained and 
showed no focal lesion that could cause seizures.  No further 
episodes occured while in the hospital. 
.  
7. Depression/ anxiety- Pt with continued symptoms at night of 
anxiety requesting klonapin. She was afraid that "she might have 
another seizure". Reassured patient, will continue with ativan 
prn. May need out pt psych eval to manage current meds (pt 
expressed desire to see psychiatrist). She was continued on SSRI 
and ativan prn.
.  
8. Hypothyroidism:  Pt was kept on her home dose of synthroid. 
.  
9. FEN: She was given a regular diet, pt asked to avoid lactose 
containing foods.  
.  
10. For prophylaxis, the pt was written for pneumoboots.  She 
did receive heparin for a 1-2 days of hospitalization, but had 
decreased platelets and the heparin was stopped. 
.

experienced similar pain before. He was given SL NTG with pain

.

.  
CARDIAC CATH performed on [**3328-5-18**] demonstrated:

.

.
Conclusions:  
The left atrium is normal in size. Left ventricular wall 
thickness, cavity size, and systolic function are normal 
(LVEF>55%). Due to suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall 
motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded. The right 
ventricular cavity is mildly dilated with focal basal free wall 
hypokinesis.  The aortic valve leaflets appear structurally

stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen.  The mitral valve 
leaflets are structurally normal. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation 
is seen. There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic 
hypertension. There is an anterior space which most likely 
represents a fat pad.  
IMPRESSION: Right ventricular cavity enlargement with basal 
hypokinesis and pulmonary artery systolic hypertension 
suggestive of primary pulmonary process (pulmonary embolism,

mitral regurgitation.

Patient is a 78 year old man with no previously known coronary

Admission Date:  [**3135-5-6**]     Discharge Date:  [**3135-5-28**]

Date of Birth:   [**3098-1-30**]     Sex:  M


HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:   [**Known patient firstname **] [**Known patient lastname 10245**] is a 37 year
old male who originally noticed the development of jaundice
approximately one month prior to admission.  He was referred
by his primary care doctor to the [**Hospital1 **] Liver

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1.  The patient has had surgery in the past for a question of
some type of hepatic adenoma.
2.  Migraines.
3.  Hypertension.
4.  Hypothyroidism.
MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION:
1.  Zestril.
2.  Topamax.
3.  Levoxyl.
4.  Nadolol.

FAMILY HISTORY:  Significant for a mother who had colon
cancer at the age of 49.

LABORATORY:  After being seen in the Liver Clinic, the
patient had a CT scan with contrast of his abdomen and
pelvis.  An obvious 20 centimeters hypervascular mass
occupying the lateral segment of the left hepatic lobe is
present on the CT scan.  This mass appeared to be compressing
the portal vein, inferior vena cava and hepatic artery,
although there was no definite evidence of vascular invasion.

There was also a large right pleural effusion seen on the
scan.

To further clarify the characteristics of the tumor, an MRI
was scheduled for [**4-30**].  This MRI showed that this mass
had significant mass effect upon the inferior vena cava.  The
inferior vena cava is displaced right to left across the
midline from the mass, which again does not show invasive
features.

The patient also underwent preoperative laboratory studies.
Preoperatively, the patient's white blood cell count is 7.3,
hematocrit 32.5, platelets 157, creatinine 1.2, ALT 41, AST
79, alkaline phosphatase 227, total bilirubin 6.9, amylase
28, lipase 81; INR 1.4.  CEA 1.4.  AST 1.2.

HOSPITAL COURSE:   On [**3135-5-7**], the patient thus
underwent a caudate lobectomy of the liver.  Please see the
Operative Note for further details.  Towards the end of the
operation, the patient was somewhat coagulopathic as he had
received several units of blood products, including at least
35 units of packed red blood cells.  Towards the end of the
procedure, he had a platelet count of 55,000 and an INR of
2.9.  There was oozing of blood from the liver bed.  Attempts
to control this blood with Argon beam, topical thrombin,
Bio-Glue, Serpasil, Gelfoam with thrombin were all
unsuccessful.

Therefore, the liver bed was packed with laparotomy pads.
The decision was made at this time in the Operating Room to
pack the patient and return at 48 hours for removal of the
packs.  The abdomen was closed using running #1-0 PDS for the
linear [**Female First Name (un) 4815**]; two [**Location (un) 1275**]-[**Location (un) **] drains were left; one superior
to the liver and one inferior to the liver.

The patient then had an extended stay in the Intensive Care
Unit.  He was intubated for several days.  He required blood
pressure support with Levophed for [**5-6**], [**5-7**], and
[**5-8**].  The Levophed was discontinued on [**5-9**].  He
required intubation for several days.  He was taken back to
the Operating Room on [**5-9**], at which time the laparotomy
pads were removed from his abdomen.  He was then closed
primarily and was extubated on [**5-13**], successfully.

The patient was transferred to the Floor on [**5-14**].  On
[**5-15**], the patient was started on p.o. intake.  He began
to spike fevers frequently, up to 101.9ï¿½ï¿½F.  At this time, he
had several cultures sent.  He has three open areas in his
Chevron incision.  Each of those wounds was swabbed and sent
for Gram stain and culture.  Both [**Location (un) 1275**]-[**Location (un) **] drains were
cultured.  Blood cultures, urine cultures and sputum culture
were also sent.  He had several cultures resent over the next
several days for recurrence of fevers.

One of the [**Location (un) 1275**]-[**Location (un) **] drains at one point in time grew out
Staphylococcus coagulase negative; this was the only
significant finding and was only seen in one sample on one
occasion.  Infectious Disease was involved and he was started
on Vancomycin and Imipenem on [**5-14**].  He went on to
complete a 14-day course of Imipenem and Vancomycin and then
these were discontinued on [**5-28**].

The patient continued to have fevers, so a CT scan was
ordered on [**5-18**].  The CT scan revealed no abscess,
however, did reveal a clot in the inferior vena cava; thus,
the patient was started on a heparin drip.  This inferior
vena cava clot was probably contributing to the tremendous
amount of fluids he had in his lower extremities and he was
being diuresed every day with Lasix.  The patient was started
on Coumadin on [**5-21**], in an attempt to be able to
anti-coagulate him with oral medication.  Of significance,
one of his [**Location (un) 1275**]-[**Location (un) **] drains was discontinued on [**5-17**],
and the second one was discontinued on [**5-19**].  He had a
considerable amount of seepage from the [**Location (un) 1275**]-[**Location (un) **] sites.
These were stitched and there was still a considerable amount
of seepage.  They were re-stitched more securely on [**5-27**],
and then there was very little seepage.

The patient was kept in-house until [**5-28**], to complete a
14-day course of Vancomycin and Imipenem.

The pathology from his operation came back hepatic-cellular
carcinoma, well differentiated, with extensive necrosis.
There is invasion of the attached fibrous tissue structure
and no normal liver tissue was seen.

The patient's INR came up to 1.9 on discharge date of [**5-28**] and the patient was tolerating a regular diet and stable
for discharge to home with Visiting Nurses Association care.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
1.  Visiting Nurses Association scheduled for INR value on
Thursday, [**5-30**], and call Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 657**] with the results of that,
so his Coumadin dosage can be adjusted.
2.  Visiting Nurses Association will also do dressing changes
twice daily.
3.  The patient is to follow-up with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 657**] on [**6-11**], in
[**Hospital Ward Name 463**]-7 at 03:30 p.m.
4.  The patient is also to follow-up with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1147**] of
Oncology.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
1.  Lasix 40 mg p.o. q. day.
2.  Topamax 25 mg p.o. q. day.
3.  Protonix 40 mg p.o. q. day.
4.  Levoxyl 0.1 mg p.o. q. day.
5.  Nadolol 160 mg p.o. q. day.
6.  Zestril 25 mg p.o. q. day.
7.  Coumadin 7.5 mg p.o. q. day.

.

.
MR L spine [**7-12**]: FINDINGS: No comparisons are available.
.
There is large area of destruction involving the L1/2 disc with

.

represent a small post-procedure hematoma
.
CT chest [**7-15**]: IMPRESSION:
1. Osseous destruction at L1-2 with paravertebral soft tissue 
consistent with osteomyelitis/discitis, better demonstrated on 
recent MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**3268-7-12**]. Evaluation of the central canal is 
limited on CT.

2. Bilateral pulmonary consolidation and pleural effusions, 
likely representing pulmonary edema, although superimposed

.

Mild-to-moderate cardiomegaly is stable and there is no 
appreciable pleural effusion. There has been interval increase 
in thickness of the right paratracheal and mediastinal soft 
tissue probably combination of azygos vein distention, 
mediastinal fat deposition, and some increase in central 
adenopathy. Left supraclavicular dual-channel dialysis catheter 
has been advanced to the lower third of the SVC. There is no

.

likely pulmonary hemorrhage.
.

1. Abnormal focal osseous uptake along the right aspect of the 
L1 and L2
vertebral bodies which may represent osteomyelitis, though
